awd_titl_txt: Conference: Strong Coupling with Organic Molecules (SCOM-23)
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION

This award is to support the 2023 Strong Coupling with Organic Molecules 2023 Conference, to be held June 20 through 22, 2023, in San Diego, California. The conference will provide an important platform within the U.S. for the efficient exchange of ideas in the burgeoning field of molecular polaritonics. Polaritons are unique electronic state arising from strong coupling of electromagnetic waves with a material with an electric or magnetic dipole when optically excited. This will be the first time that the conference will be held in the United States, providing an opportunity to the leadership of the U.S. in the scientific discourse of the field. The event will showcase recent progress and challenges in the field, generate a cohesive community of researchers, and promote the exploitation of strong light-matter interactions to control the physicochemical properties of molecular materials. This award will provide support for early career scientists to attend the meeting and benefit from discussions and presentation of their work.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION

This conference will serve as an important platform  for the efficient exchange of ideas in the burgeoning field of molecular polaritonics. The event will showcase recent progress and challenges in the field, contribute to generating a cohesive community of researchers, and promote the exploitation of strong light-matter interactions to control the electronic and photonic properties of molecular materials. Molecular polaritonics have already demonstrated control of energy transduction and novel macroscopic quantum coherent phenomena such as room-temperature Bose-Einstein condensates. Many of the mechanisms that underlie these phenomena remain unknown, and significant advances are needed on both the theoretical and experimental sides to develop robust technologies based on molecular polaritons. In particular, the processes of controlling energy transduction by polaritonics and quantum logic operations by polariton condensates hold great. Overall, this conference aims to address the challenges and prospects of the field of polaritonics and foster development of next generation optoelectronic and photonic materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF-supported project organized the biennial "Strong Coupling of Organic Molecules (SCOM) 2023" conference, which aimed to gather the international community of researchers exploring the unique physicochemical properties emerging from strong coupling between confined photonic excitations and molecular excitations such as vibrations and molecular excitons. This was the first time the conference was held in the U.S. and the first in-person meeting post-COVID-19 for the polariton chemistry community. The conference hosted 92 participants, including invited and contributed speakers, and featured 26 invited talks (30 minutes each), 8 contributed talks (20 minutes each), and 43 posters across two afternoon poster sessions. The event served as a platform for North American, European, and Asian researchers to present their work, network, and shape the direction of the field. The grant in particular was used to support participants with social-economical disadvantaged background and underpresentative groups.

A final roundtable discussion identified emerging trends and challenges in strong coupling research, emphasizing interdisciplinary collaboration and setting the stage for future breakthroughs. The conference showcased a diverse array of material systems embedded in various photonic architectures, from Fabry-Pérot microcavities to plasmonic nanocavities. It highlighted molecular polaritons as a novel class of hybrid materials with unique physicochemical properties that offer potential applications in chemical catalysis and optoelectronic devices. This focus reinforced the importance of interdisciplinary approaches, with significant contributions from researchers in Electronic and Photonic materials, Physical and Materials Chemistry, Chemical Physics, and Condensed Matter Physics.

SCOM 2023 also provided ample opportunities for researchers at all levels to network and present their work. Contributed talks were assigned to junior PIs, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows, and two poster sessions encouraged scientific interaction. Three poster awards were given, with the recipients delivering lightning talks. An online special issue of Nanophotonics is being curated to collect peer-reviewed research articles from conference participants and is expected to be published by summer 2024.

The conference significantly impacted the discipline of Electronic and Photonic materials by promoting molecular polaritons as a novel class of hybrid materials with unique physicochemical properties. It emphasized the importance of controlling chemical reactions through strong coupling between electronic, vibrational, and photonic degrees of freedom. Additionally, the conference demonstrated the potential for molecular polaritons to catalyze novel technologies in synthetic chemistry and optoelectronics.

SCOM 2023 also fostered important interdisciplinary collaborations, catalyzing cross-disciplinary research between Physical and Materials Chemistry, Chemical Physics, and Condensed Matter Physics. By integrating experimental, theoretical, and computational tools, researchers aimed to advance the understanding of polariton chemistry and uncover the fundamental mechanisms underlying polariton-mediated chemical control.

In addition to fostering scientific leadership and collaboration, the conference made a significant impact on training and educational experiences. It supported the participation of PIs, postdoctoral fellows, and graduate students, providing opportunities to present talks and posters and improve their scientific communication skills. The roundtable discussion at the end of the conference allowed all participants to contribute ideas on the future directions of polariton chemistry.

Beyond science and technology, SCOM 2023 showcased the scientific leadership of U.S.-based researchers in polariton chemistry. It facilitated important networking opportunities between U.S. and international researchers, strengthening the global research community in this field. The conference reinforced the strategic importance of the U.S. in leading cutting-edge research on hybrid light-matter systems.

In summary, SCOM 2023 successfully brought together an international community of researchers to advance the field of polariton chemistry. By providing a platform for collaboration and showcasing the forefront of research in strong coupling, the conference reinforced the importance of interdisciplinary approaches and established the U.S. as a scientific leader in polariton chemistry research. It laid the groundwork for future breakthroughs by fostering a collaborative, interdisciplinary approach to understanding the unique physicochemical properties of strongly coupled systems.
